Award.AwardTitle: Quantitative Salinity & Water D/H from Paired H & C Isotopes in Mangrove Lipids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Global patterns of rainfall have been changing over the last half-century, impacting the lives of people worldwide. A full understanding of these changes has not yet emerged, but they have been linked to a warming of global temperatures in response to the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Among the more widespread changes in precipitation have occurred in the tropics, where wet regions have been getting wetter and dry regions drier. It remains unknown whether the changes in tropical rainfall observed over the last 30 years are unusual when viewed on a multi-century or multi-millennial time scale. As yet it is therefore not possible to say whether recent precipitation trends are outside the range of natural variability. Any such conclusion will require records of rainfall from the tropics extending back in time a thousand years or more. But at present there are few, if any methods to accurately reconstruct rainfall in most locations on the planet prior to the advent of rain gauges and satellites, especially in the maritime tropics. The goal of this project is to develop a method for determining the salinity and deuterium-to-hydrogen ratio of water, two parameters very closely linked to rainfall in the tropics, from the chemistry of mangrove lipids that can be recovered from ocean and lake sediment cores.

Mangroves are remarkable trees that have adapted to living in saltwater. They inhabit the intertidal zones of the global tropics and subtropics. The approach of the proposed study is based upon the investigator's recent observation that the ratio of both deuterium (2H) to hydrogen (1H) and carbon-13 (13C) to carbon-12 (12C) in the lipids of mangrove leaves changes systematically when the salinity of the water in which they live changes. This study will calibrate that response in multiple species of mangroves by growing them in the laboratory at a range of different salinities. The investigator will then test whether those calibrations are consistent when applied to multiple mangrove species inhabiting the shorelines of saline lakes on the tropical island of Palau that span a wide range of salinities. Because the hydrogen isotope composition of mangrove lipids incorporates the deuterium-to-hydrogen ratio of the water in which the mangroves live, as well as the salinity of that water, and the carbon isotopes only respond to the salinity, it is possible to calculate both the salinity and the hydrogen isotope ratio of the coastal water. From these two parameters one can make good estimates of rainfall, since both the salinity and the deuterium-to-hydrogen ratio of coastal water decreases when rainfall increases. When measured on mangrove lipids extracted from sediment cores taken in coastal settings and maritime lakes it will be possible to reconstruct rainfall estimates back in time, thus providing the long-term view needed to conclude whether recent trends in tropical rainfall are outside the range of natural variability.

This project is supported jointly by the Marine Geology and Geophysics Program in the NSF Division of Ocean Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rainfall patterns in the tropics and subtropics have changed over the last four decades. Owing to the complexity of the climate system and an imperfect understanding of tropical precipitation, the underlying causes of these changes are not well understood. However, climate theory suggests that these trends are likely to continue if greenhouse gas levels in the atmosphere continue to rise. One of the primary impediments to improved rainfall projections is the short instrumental record of precipitation, which for most of the globe, began just 35 years ago with the widespread use of weather satellites. The only way to extend the rainfall record back in time is through indirect means. The goal of this project was therefore to develop a new approach to reconstruct tropical and subtropical rainfall from hydrogen and carbon isotope ratios in lipids produced by mangrove trees that inhabit intertidal regions in low latitudes of the planet.


Using a combination of field and laboratory studies this research demonstrated that there is a sensitive biochemical and biophysical response of mangrove trees to salinity, that causes systematic changes in both the hydrogen and carbon isotope composition of lipids in mangrove leaves. Specifically, when salinity increases, hydrogen isotope fractionation in mangrove lipids increases by about 1 part per thousand, and carbon isotope fractionation systematically decreases by 0.2 parts per thousand, per unit increase in salinity. When these two responses are combined, both the salinity and the hydrogen isotopic composition of water in which the mangrove trees grew can be reconstructed. Because these two parameters are very sensitive to rainfall, rainfall in the past can be estimated by measuring the hydrogen and carbon isotope composition of mangrove lipids in coastal sediments.


Another outcome of this research was the finding that mangrove trees have the opposite hydrogen isotope response to salinity as phytoplankton. So while hydrogen isotope fractionation increases with salinity in mangroves, it decreases in phytoplankton. Calibrations of these two responses developed during this research, were applied to reconstruct rainfall over the eastern tropical Pacific Ocean during the last 2,000 years from the measurement of hydrogen isotope ratios in mangrove and phytoplankton lipids in sediment cores from coastal ponds on the Galápagos Islands. These results indicate that, compared to today, the tropical rain band, known as the Intertropical Convergence Zone, was located significantly closer to the equator from 1500-1850 A.D (see top panel of figure 1). This period is referred to as the ‘Little Ice Age’ since Europe and North America experienced much harsher winters than in the centuries before or after (see, for example, northern hemisphere air temperature record in bottom panel of figure 1).


The research activities contributed to the betterment of society through, among other things, two workshops on mangroves and climate for school teachers in Kosrae, Micronesia, and a 3-week experiential learning course for University of Washington undergraduate students in Kosrae. During the 5-credit course entitled “OCEAN 496: Coastal Ecosystems of Micronesia in a Changing Climate”, 15 students studied the mangrove, coral reef, and seagrass ecosystems surrounding Kosrae, and how they are being impacted by climate change and anthropogenic activities. Rapid ecological assessments of pristine and anthropogenically impacted systems were conducted in partnership with local government agencies and non-governmental organizations. Throughout the course the students were immersed in the local culture, food and customs. One of the two teacher workshops was incorporated into the curriculum of the OCEAN 496 class, providing the 15 University of Washington undergraduate students the unique opportunity to become teachers, educating Kosraean K-8 teachers in one-to-one and small group encounters on the unique attributes that allow mangrove trees to live in the intertidal zone, their role in preventing shoreline erosion, and their vulnerability to climate change. As part of the workshop the teachers learned  how much salt is in seawater, its origin, and how to measure it with a handheld refractometer. The students then worked with each teacher to create a grade-appropriate poster conveying some aspect of what they learned about mangroves and seawater to be displayed in their classroom and used as the centerpiece of a lesson (see figure 2).
